@lbourgon half the entire Muslim population in Canada is located in Ontario, it's surprising that the first mosque was established in YEG
here's how Al-Rashid Mosque looks now. every mosque built in Canada since is the result of the love and cooperationâ€¦ https://t.co/bSZ5ZghApl
Muslims have always been a part of our Canadian identity and Canadian history, and it's important to not lose sight of that.
though it was nearly lost, people were able to realize what an important building it is, & its place in Edmontonian and Canadian history.
Hamdon's granddaughter Karen and friends raised the necessary $75,000 to have the mosque moved to its current location in Fort Edmonton Park
the mosque would need that communal support again in 1988 when it was nearly demolished for a hospital expansion.
it was a community project, designed in the style of an Orthodox church by a Ukrainian-Canadian builder, with funds raised across the city
Mayor Fry agreed to provide the land for a mosque if Hamdon could raise the funds. the $5000 sum needed was raised by going door to door.
Edmonton just named a school after Hamdon (it opened just this fall). this is her story, told by her granddaughter: https://t.co/vyUxEAYqCP
it was a Lebanese-Canadian woman, Hilwie Hamdon, who first brought the idea of a mosque to Edmonton's mayor, John Fry
the Muslim community in Edmonton was 20 families strong. many were Syrians, having fled from conscription into the Ottoman army.
the first mosque in Canada was built in 1938, in Edmonton of all places.
